qas.question: what is a perfect example of a filled vacuum showing a curvature?
Who's equations  helped to imply vanishing of the Ricci tensor?
what produces curvature in a vacuum?
What kind of electric charge does a vanishing stress-energy tensor have?
What is a black hole a part of?
What field around the Earth was discovered by Einstein?
Tidal forces and gravitational waves can produce zero what?
What is the shape of a gravitational field?

context: In general relativity, a vanishing stress-energy tensor implies, through <a1_0>Einstein<a1_0/> field equations, the vanishing of all the components of the Ricci tensor. Vacuum does not mean that the curvature of space-time is necessarily <b8_0>flat<b8_0/>: the <b6_0>gravitational field<b6_0/> can still produce curvature in a vacuum in the form of <a2_0>tidal forces and gravitational waves<a2_0/> (technically, these phenomena are the components of <b5_0>the Weyl tensor<b5_0/>). <a0_0>The <a3_0>black hole<a3_0/><a0_0/> (with <b4_0>zero<b4_0/> <b7_0>electric charge<b7_0/>) is an elegant example of a region completely "filled" with vacuum, but still showing a strong curvature.
